titleStmt.title: Letter from William Marsh to Mary Anne Rawson
titleStmt.author: William Marsh

publicationStmt.p: This is a born-digital diplomatic transcription of an unpublished letter.

sourceDesc.p: Written on two sides of a sheet of wove paper. JRL labeled this "123".

div.p: I have been by the [Ladies?] Will this letter be of any service in your projected work? I rejoice that zeal is manifested in this, & every way, for this great object.

I send you a proof that these Blacks have minds as well as Whites. And, of a truth, they feel the indignities put upon them, & the pain of having their blood whipped through their skins, quite as much as we should do.

All that we ask is, that British subjects should have the privileges protections of British Laws. As to Arbitrary Power,
no Creature in existence is capable
of employing it aright. I would not willingly live under the Government of an Angel, if I thought he could forget that he himself was amenable to his Creator ^But I rejoice to live under the Government of my Saviour, because He cannot do? . And when all submit to His Government, all will be happy. But Alas, how many Masters in the West Indies neither regard God nor Man. The Measure of ingenuity is nearly full. It will be a wonderful proof of the Divine Patience & Mercy, if Slavery end by the means now proposed. If the West Indies continue in their infatuation, they will lose all without remedy. How thankful should Britain be. I know few things that disgust me more than to hear an Englishman say, "The Blacks are as well off in the W. Inds, as our Labourers here." It is something worse than a lie a falsehood of the worst description. The English Peasant lives in his own Country, is actually free, & knows that his children will be the same & that he can speak his mind without the fear of the lashes that he cannot ever be struck with impunity, & that he partakes, equally with his superiors, of the protection of the Law—Not one of these advantages does the African Slave possess.

The following are the lines of Phillis, a negro & the Slave of Mr Wheately of Boston, in a hymn on the Evening.
"Fill'd with the praise of Him who gives the light,
And draws the Sable Curtains of the Night,
Let placed Slumbers sooth each weary mind,
At Morn to wake more heav'nly & refined;
So shall the labours of the day begin
More pure & guarded from the snares of sin." She writes as follows, on Imagination
"Imagination! who can sing thy force
Or who describe the swiftness of thy course?
Soaring through air to find the bright abode,
Th' Empyreal palace of the thund'ring God.
We on thy pinions can surpass the wind
And leave the rolling universe behind;
From star to star, the mental optics rove,
Measure the skies, & range the realms above;
There in one view we grasp the mighty whole,
Or with New Worlds, amaze th' unbound Soul."
Are Blacks only connecting links between Whites & Brutes?

If you would like 2 or 3 Anecdotes of Blacks, or any further remarks on any part of , I will forward to you. God grant a blessing on your undertaking. Let us all praise God to influence the hearts of parties concerned, that the Slaves may be free, the Owner be protected, & our Country delivered from such a load of guilt.

closer.salute:
I am
Dear Madam
yrs very truly,
